collect_data

collect_data.Rmd
library(safetymeta)
library(meta)
#> Loading required package: metadat
#> Loading 'meta' package (version 7.0-0).
#> Type 'help(meta)' for a brief overview.
#> Readers of 'Meta-Analysis with R (Use R!)' should install
#> older version of 'meta' package: https://tinyurl.com/dt4y5drs

Once safety meta-analysis has been performed, it is natural to collect numerical results on the model(s).

Although not specific of safety meta-analysis, the package provides the table_mod_summary function to table those summary results.

This is especially useful when there are multiple models, e.g, when studying more than one event, or performing subgroup analyses.

data <-
    data.frame(
      event_a = 4:1,
      event_b = 1:4,
      n = c(5, 7, 8, 9),
      byvar = c("a", "a", "b", "b")
    )

 m_a <- metaprop(
    event = event_a,
    n = n,
    byvar = byvar,
    data = data
  )
 
 

table_mod_summary(m_a)
#>       analysis mod_name event  n n stud/I2     Proportion (95%CI)      per
#> 1 main outcome      mod    10 29     4/47% 344.83 (196.62-530.93) 1000 pts
#>    method_sm_effects TE.random lower.random upper.random k        I2
#> 1 GLMM PLOGIT common 0.3448276    0.1966169    0.5309271 4 0.4681994

If studying two events, use a named list of models


m_b <- metaprop(
    event = event_b,
    n = n,
    byvar = byvar,
    data = data
  )


table_mod_summary(
     list(mod_a = m_a,
          mod_b = m_b)
   )
#>       analysis mod_name event  n n stud/I2     Proportion (95%CI)      per
#> 1 main outcome    mod_a    10 29     4/47% 344.83 (196.62-530.93) 1000 pts
#> 2 main outcome    mod_b    10 29      4/0% 344.83 (196.62-530.93) 1000 pts
#>    method_sm_effects TE.random lower.random upper.random k        I2
#> 1 GLMM PLOGIT common 0.3448276    0.1966169    0.5309271 4 0.4681994
#> 2 GLMM PLOGIT common 0.3448276    0.1966175    0.5309262 4 0.0000000

Notice that the names of the model list are collected into the mod_name column. Providing enough data in these names makes it easy to track the results in subsequent data management steps.

If studying subgroups, use argument main_or_sbgp.


m_a |> 
  table_mod_summary(
    main_or_sbgp = "sbgp"
  )
#>    analysis mod_name bylevs event  n n stud/I2     Proportion (95%CI)      per
#> a subgroups      mod      a     7 12     2/35% 583.33 (307.64-815.19) 1000 pts
#> b subgroups      mod      b     3 17      2/0%  176.47 (58.01-427.15) 1000 pts
#>    method_sm_effects   p TE.random lower.random upper.random pval.Q.b.common
#> a GLMM PLOGIT common .03 0.5833333   0.30764226    0.8151925       0.0299519
#> b GLMM PLOGIT common .03 0.1764706   0.05800932    0.4271476       0.0299519
#>   k.w      I2.w
#> a   2 0.3457515
#> b   2 0.0000000

For meta::metaprop models, table_mod_summary only works if sm="PLOGIT"
